title: Taiwan Defense: A Hard Problem for the U.S.
sub_head: It is inconceivable that the powerful, proud and growing menace that is China today would set itself up to lose a war over Taiwan.
body:
Perhaps Elbridge Colby is right—it may be time to clearly define where we stand with regard to China (“America Can Defend Taiwan,” op-ed, Jan. 27).
It is inconceivable that the powerful, proud and growing menace that is China today would set itself up to lose a war over Taiwan. Will China lay it on the line to establish, once and for all, that it will not be shoved around by the once-mighty U.S.? The advantage is almost all on the side of the Chinese.
American carrier battle groups within hundreds of miles of the Chinese coast would have difficulty surviving a coordinated attack by many hundreds of Chinese ground-, air- and sea-launched missiles, some hypersonic.
Anyone with even a passing memory of the Chinese involvement in the Korean War knows they will not shrink from very heavy casualties to carry out their war aims. Will the extremely war-weary American public stand by for this unnecessary slaughter?
Bart McPherson
